data.text: Contents
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to providing high quality, compassionate care at all times. However, it is recognised that there will be occasions when patients and service users do not consider that their expectations have been met and issues or concerns arise relating to care or services provided by the Trust.

All Trust staff are expected to respond to issues and concerns in a positive and helpful manner and encourage early resolution of issues at ward and departmental (local) level. All staff are expected to use the feedback from concerns and complaints to drive service improvements and commit to improve patient experience.
The Trust acknowledges the rights of patients, relatives and carers under the NHS Constitution which states that they:
Have the right to have any complaint made about NHS services acknowledged within three working days and to have it properly investigated and responded to.
Have the right to discuss the manner in which the complaint is to be handled, and to know the period within which the investigation is likely to be completed and the response sent.

Have the right to be kept informed of the progress and to know the outcome of any investigation into the complaint, including an explanation of the conclusions and confirmation that any action needed in consequence of the complaint has been taken or is proposed to be taken.

Have the right to take the complaint to the independent Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman (PHSO) or Local Government Ombudsman; if they are not satisfied with the way the complaint has been dealt with by the NHS.
The Trust also pledges to:

Ensure that complainants are treated with courtesy and that they receive appropriate support throughout the handling of a complaint; the fact that they have complained will not adversely affect their future treatment.

Ensure that when mistakes happen or if a patient is harmed while receiving health care that they receive an appropriate explanation and apology, delivered with sensitivity and recognition of the trauma experienced, and know that lessons will be learned to help avoid a similar incident occurring again.

Use concerns and complaints as a tool for the organisation to monitor its performance and review areas that require improvement. Concerns and complaints therefore contribute to an important part of the Trust's overall approach to clinical governance and patient safety and experience.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to give all staff clear guidance on how complaints are managed to ensure a consistent, fair and just approach to all those involved in a complaint.

The Trust is committed to promoting an environment that values diversity. Any patient who makes a complaint, or any other person involved in the investigation and resolution of a complaint, will be treated equally and fairly and will not be discriminated against because a complaint has been made or on the grounds of race, sex, disability, religion, age, sexual orientation or any other unjustifiable reason.

Attention will be given to employees and service users for whom English is not their first language, who have a visual impairment or other disability, ensuring they understand and are able to benefit from this policy.

Set out the Trust's policy and process for the proper acknowledgment, investigation and resolution of complaints and concerns raised by patients and service users. This policy follows the relevant requirements as given in the Local Authority, Social Services and National Health Service Complaint Regulations 2009 (‘the 2009 Regulations').

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Overall responsibility and accountability for the management of complaints lies with the responsible person. In our organisation this is the Chief Executive.

We have processes in place to ensure our senior managers regularly review complaints alongside other forms of feedback. They will make sure action is taken on all identified learning arising from complaints so that improvements are made to our services.
Our senior managers demonstrate this by:
Leading by example to improve the way we deal with compliments, feedback, concerns and complaints
Understanding the obstacles people face when making a complaint or raising a concern and taking action to improve the experience by removing them
Knowing and complying with all relevant legal requirements regarding complaints
Making information available in a format that people find easy to understand
Promoting information about independent complaints advocacy and advice services
Making sure everyone knows when a complaint is a serious incident or safeguarding or legal issue and what must happen
Making sure that there is a strong commitment to the duty of candour so there is a culture of being open and honest when something goes wrong
Making sure we listen and learn from concerns/complaints and improve services when something goes wrong.

The Associate Director for Patient Experience and Engagement is responsible for managing the complaints management procedure and overseeing the handling and consideration of any complaints we receive.

The 2009 Regulations allow the Trust to delegate the relevant functions of the responsible person and complaints management to our staff where appropriate. We do this to ensure we can provide an efficient and responsive service. The roles and responsibilities of staff within our organisation and relevant delegated functions when dealing with complaints are set out in Appendix
As an overview all Trust Staff are expected to:
Take any concern raised by a patient or their family seriously, to act compassionately, to listen and to view it as an opportunity to learn and improve the care that can be given to future patients.
Make every effort to resolve concerns and complaints when they are raised within their ward/department, and know who to escalate the issue to if they are unable to resolve the concerns personally.
Be aware of and follow the Trust's Complaints Policy. All staff need to know how and where to find information about the PALS & Complaints Teams for patients and relatives, should they request it.
Have a duty to ensure that no patient is discriminated against or their care adversely affected following any concerns or complaints.
Engage with the PALS & Complaints Teams and follow the complaints
process set out in this policy.
Identifying a complaint
Everyday Conversations with our users

5.1.1 Our staff speak to people who use our service every day. This can often raise issues that our staff can help with immediately. We encourage people to discuss any issues with our staff, as we may be able to sort the issue to their satisfaction quickly and without the need for them to contact PALS or make a complaint.

5.1.2 The Trust is keen to seek feedback from our patients and their families. Proactive publicity is used to raise awareness and help patients know how to give feedback and know how to make a complaint (e.g. staff awareness, posters, leaflets, website).
When people want to make a complaint

5.2.1 We recognise that we cannot always resolve issues as they arise and that sometimes people want to make a complaint. A complaint is an expression of dissatisfaction, either spoken or written, that requires a response. It can be about:
An act, omission or decision we have made
The standard of service we have provided
5.2.2 Complaints can be made to us:
In person
By phone
In writing, by letter, email or online
5.2.3 We will consider all accessibility and reasonable adjustment requirements of people who wish to make a complaint in an alternative way. We will record any reasonable adjustment we make.

5.2.4 The Trust ensures it distinguishes and logs feedback appropriately, relating to the type of feedback and whether concerns are raised or not. Where no concerns are raised this is logged as an enquiry, feedback where concerns are raised and can be/should be addressed swiftly through the PALS process are logged as PALS concerns, and feedback where a full investigation and a full written response are required are logged as a formal complaint. This decision is undertaken upon receipt by the PALS and Complaints Team, often with liaison with the complainant/patient.

5.2.5 Where possible concerns should be addressed through the PALS route by the appropriate division. This ensures swift contact with the complainant and aims to bring a speedy resolution, with an aim to prevent the need for a formal complaint to be raised.
5.2.6 The Complaints staff will acknowledge all complaints within three working days of receipt. This can be done in writing or verbally.

5.2.7 The Trust may receive an anonymous or a general complaint that would not meet the criteria for a complaint. In this case we would normally take a look into the matter to identify if there is any learning for our organisation unless there is a reason not to do so.
Who can make a complaint

Any person may make a complaint to the Trust if they have received or are receiving care and services from our organisation. A person may also complain to us if they are affected or likely to be affected by any action, inaction or decision by our organisation.

If someone other than the patient contacts the PALS & Complaints Team or Trust to raise a concern or complaint, consideration should be made as to whether the concerns raised can be answered without disclosing confidential information about the patient. Consideration should also be taken to establish whether the concerns raised are not in relation to the patient's care, and therefore confidential information would not need to be disclosed (for example, if the complaint was about the complainant's experience when speaking with staff).

If confidential information needs to be disclosed, then consent will be required from the patient to enable the Trust to respond to the complainant. The PALS & Complaints Team will obtain verbal consent from the patient (and document this within complaint file on the Datix Database) to proceed with the appropriate investigation process. The exception to this will be if the complaint is:
Following triage within the Complaints Team, the case is identified as a potentially serious matter (a “Red” RAG Rated complaint) see section 8.12
The complaint involves an external organisation
The patient lacks capacity
In these circumstances written consent will be obtained from the patient or the relevant proof of Power of Attorney (POA) will be sought.

If the patient lacks capacity, proof of Power of Attorney for Health & Wellbeing will be required in order to disclose confidential information about a patient. Where this is not available, the PALS & Complaints Team will seek advice from the PALS & Complaints Management Team who can highlight this and obtain advice from the relevant team(s) such as the Legal Team, the Information Governance Team or the Safeguarding Team, to ensure each case is considered on an individual basis, taking
into account what information will need to be disclosed during the investigation/response.

Where complaints are raised about the care of a deceased patient, we should ensure we either have a valid Power of Attorney for Health and Welfare or if this is not available we should obtain consent from the next of kin documented on the electronic patient record. Although the patient is deceased we still have a duty of confidentiality to this patient.

The PALS & Complaints Team will not send a complaint to the division(s) for investigation and response until consent has been received into the PALS & Complaints Team. The exception to this is in the case of complaints triaged as being “Red”, where the concerns raised are appear extremely serious in nature and require immediate action/review. However, a response will not be provided to the complainant until appropriate consent has been received.

On occasions, complaints will be made to the Trust via a Member of Parliament (MP) on behalf of a patient or member of the public. The PALS & Complaints Team ensure that MP cases are monitored and responded to and that consent is obtained when necessary.

If at any time we see that a representative is not acting in the best interests of the person affected we will assess whether we should stop our consideration of the complaint. If we do this, we will share our reasons with the representative in writing. In such circumstances we will advise the representative that they may complain to the PHSO if they are unhappy with our decision.
Timescale for making a complaint

Complaints must be made to the Trust within 12 months of the date the incident being complained about happened or the date the person raising the complaint found out about it, whichever is the later date.
If a complaint is made to us after that 12 month deadline we will consider it if:
We believe there were good reasons for not making the complaint before the deadline and;
It is still possible to properly consider the complaint effectively and fairly

If we do not see a good reason for the delay or we think it is not possible to properly consider the complaint (or any part of it) we will write to the person making the complaint to explain this. We will also explain that, if they are dissatisfied with that decision, they can complain to the PHSO.
Complaints and other procedures

We make sure our complaints staff are properly trained to identify when it may not be possible to achieve a relevant outcome through the complaints process on its own. Where this happens staff will inform the person making the complaint and give them information about any other process that may help to address the issues and has the potential to provide the outcomes sought.
This can happen at any stage in the complaint handling process and may include identifying issues that could or should:
Trigger a patient safety investigation
Involve a coroner investigation or inquest
Trigger a relevant regulatory process, such as fitness to practice investigations or referrals
Involve a relevant legal issue that requires specialist advice or guidance

When another process may be better suited to cover other potential outcomes, our staff will seek advice and provide clear information to the individual raising the complaint. We will make sure the individual understands why this is relevant and the options available. We will also signpost the individual to sources of specialist independent advice.

This will not prevent us from continuing to investigate the complaint. We will make sure the person raising the complaint gets a complete and holistic response to all issues raised, which includes any outcomes where appropriate. Our complaints staff will engage with other staff or organisations who can provide advice and support on the best way to do this.

If an individual is already taking part or chooses to take part in another process but wishes to continue with their complaint as well, this will not affect the investigation and response to the complaint. The only exceptions to this are if:
The individual requests or agrees to a delay
There is a formal request for a pause in the complaint process from the police, a coroner or a judge
In such cases the complaint investigation will be put on hold until those processes conclude.
Complaints not suitable for Investigation under the NHS Complaints Regulations
8.7.1  The Complaints Procedure cannot be implemented if it is:
A complaint made by an NHS body which relate to the exercise of its functions by another NHS body.
A complaint made by an employee of an NHS body about any matter relating to their contract or employment.
A complaint which is being investigated or has been investigated by the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman (PHSO).

A complaint arising out of the alleged failure to comply with a request for information under the Current UK Data Protection Act 2018, or a request for information under the Freedom of Information Act 2000.

The issue of concern related to private medical care provided outside of a clinician's NHS contract. Issues relating to Trust staff or facilities concerning care in the Trust's private pay beds are not exempt from the complaints procedure.
Where the issues concerned are subject of a criminal investigation.
Any complaint that has been previously investigated by this procedure, even if made by a different person.
Complaints relating to suspected fraud and/or bribery

8.8.1 The Trust is committed to the elimination of fraud or bribery, to the rigorous investigation of any such allegations and to taking appropriate action against wrong doers, including possible criminal prosecution, as well as undertaking steps to recover assets lost as a result of fraud or bribery.
8.8.2 Fraud can be defined as any deliberate intention to make a gain for themselves or anyone else, or inflicting loss (or a risk of loss) on another.
8.8.3 Bribery can be defined as anything that induces or intends to induce improper performance.

8.8.4 Further to the Trust's Anti-Fraud and Anti-Bribery Policy (MSEPO-20238), where a complaint is received that relates to suspected fraud or bribery, the Local Counter Fraud Specialist (LCFS) or the Chief Financial Officer must be informed immediately. Staff can also call the NHS Fraud and Corruption Reporting Line on Freephone 0800 028 40 60 or report online at www.reportnhsfraud.nhs.uk.
8.8.5 The contact details for LCFS are: Mark Kidd, via email: mark.kidd@bakertilly.co.uk.
Serious Incidents & Complaints

8.9.1 Serious Incidents are managed by the Risk and Patient Safety Team. Please refer to the Trust's policy for the management of incidents and serious incidents (SIS) (MSEPO-19014). When serious incident occur a Root Cause Analysis (RCA) investigation is completed. This report looks specifically at the circumstances of the incident but often there are other issues raised within a complaint that surround the case that a patient/relative is concerned about.

8.9.2 If a complaint is triaged by the Complaints Team as “Red” (potentially serious in nature – see section 12.5) the Complaints Staff check to identify whether the issue has already been logged as an Incident on the Datix DCIQ system.

8.9.3 A RAG rating of “Red” will ensure complaints identified are immediately escalated to the appropriate Divisional Leadership Team. The Divisional Leadership Team will ensure appropriate initial review of the case and then confirm whether the case needs to be discussed at ERG (in the case of potential SI) or whether the case can

be handled through the complaints process. Any case that needs to be discussed at ERG will require a completed Initial Management Review (IMR) form, which must be sent to the Patient Safety Team 24-hours prior to the discussion at ERG.

8.9.4 If issues raised in the complaint do not relate to the specific incident being investigated through the Incident process, it is expected that the relevant division(s) will ensure that all matters raised in the complaint are investigated to provide a full response. The division(s) is expected to ensure that the results of the full investigation (the incident and the other issues raised in the complaint) will be provided to the complainant either through a meeting with provision of a report, or via a full written response.
H.M. Coroner's Office

8.10.1  Occasionally a complaint may be made after a patient's death has been referred to the Coroner's Office or during the course of a Coroner's inquest. This should not prevent the Trust's investigation from continuing and the Trust will extend investigations at the Coroner's request.
Legal representatives

8.11.1 Occasionally complaints will be raised via a complainants legal representative. This should not in itself be taken as an intention to proceed legal action although the PALS & Complaints Team will endeavour to seek clarification on this. If the sole purpose of the complaint investigation is to seek compensation from the Trust, then this will be directed to the Legal Services Team and the complainant notified of this process.

8.11.2 If a claim is made it should not prevent a full complaints investigation being carried out in the usual way. However the PALS & Complaints Team must ensure that it has received written permission from the patient to release clinical information to the legal representative. The PALS & Complaints Team will also ascertain whether the complainant wishes the Trust to respond to the legal representative or themselves.
Claims for Compensation or Clinical Negligence

8.12.1 If a complainant explicitly requests compensation in relation to clinical negligence (rather than reimbursement e.g. travel costs, lost property), this will be referred to the Legal Services Team for handling through the claims process and the complaint will be informed of the process for making a clinical negligence claim.

8.12.2 If at any stage during the handling of the complaint the complainant informs the Trust of the intention to or the commencement of the process for a clinical negligence claim, the PALS & Complaints Team will advise the appropriate senior staff in the division and the Legal Services Team. The complaint investigation will continue and if appropriate the Legal Services Team should review the final complaint response letter before it is sent.

8.12.3 In relation to ex gratia payments for lost items, travel expenses etc the PALS & Complaints Team will advise the patient/complainant that reimbursement is not guaranteed, and can only be considered with the appropriate supporting documents (i.e. proof of cost of replacement / proof of out of pocket expenses).

8.12.4 If a division investigates and decides that reimbursement should be paid they should not confirm this with the patient directly. The division should collate the information and ask for the approval of the Chief Finance Officer (CFO) for the Trust. Once this has been submitted and a decision made (either approval or refusal) then the division will need to inform the complainant of the decision. If approval is given for payment, then payment should be raised and made. See Appendix 3 for Ex-gratia payment process
Confidentiality of Complaints

We commit to maintaining confidentiality and protecting privacy throughout the complaints process in accordance with UK General Protection Data Regulation and Data Protection Act 2018. We will only collect and disclose information to those staff who are involved in the consideration of the complaint. Documents relating to a complaint investigation are securely stored and kept separately from medical records. They are only accessible to staff involved in the consideration of the complaint.
Complaint outcomes may be anonymised and shared within our organisation and may be published on our website to promote service improvement.
How we handle complaints
Making sure people know how to complain and where to get support

10.1.1 We publish clear information about our complaints process and how people can get advice and support with their complaint through their local independent NHS complaints advocacy service and other specialist independent advice services that operate nationally.

10.1.2 We will make sure that everybody who uses our services (and those that support them) know how they can make a complaint by having our complaints policy and/or materials that promote our procedure visible in public areas and on our website. We will provide a range of ways to do this so that people can do this easily in a way that suits them. This includes providing access to our complaints process online.
10.1.3 We will make sure users on-going or future care and treatment will not be affected because they have made a complaint.
What we do when we receive a complaint

10.2.1 We want all patients, their family members and carers have a good experience while they use our services. If somebody believes the service received has not met their expectations, we encourage people to talk to staff within the ward or department they are receiving their treatment to allow staff the opportunity to address their concerns and put thing right. Alternatively the PALS Service can be contacted, who will liaise with the relevant staff to enable the concerns to be resolved promptly.

10.2.2 We want to make sure we can resolve complaints quickly as often as possible. To do that, we train our staff to proactively respond to service users and their representatives and support them to deal with any complaints raised at first point of contact.

10.2.3 All of our staff who have contact with patients, services users, or those that support them will handle complaints in a sensitive and empathetic way. Staff will make sure people are listened to, get an answer to the issues quickly wherever possible, and any learning is captured and acted on.
10.2.4 As a staff member, you are expected to:
Listen to patients to make sure they understand the issue(s)
Ask how the patient has been affected
Ask what the patient would like to happen to put things right
Carry out these actions yourself if you can (or with the support of others)
If you can't do what the patient expects/requests, you will explain to the patient why this is the case
Capture any learning if something has gone wrong, to share with colleagues and improve services for others
Complaints that can be resolved quickly at a department/ward level

10.3.1 Our frontline staff often handle concerns and complaints that can be resolved quickly at the time they are raised, or very soon after. We encourage our staff to do this as much as possible so that people get a quick and effective answer to their issues.

10.3.2 When our staff believe that an early resolution is possible, they are authorised to take action to address and resolve the issues raised, and put things right for the person raising them. This may mean giving a quick explanation or apology themselves or making sure a colleague who is more informed of the issues does. Our staff will resolve complaints in person or by telephone wherever possible.

10.3.3 When handling a concern or complaint all staff should reassure the person raising the issues that their concerns are being taken seriously, that it will be dealt with sensitively and that it will not adversely affect their care or treatment.
10.3.4 If front line staff cannot resolve a concern they should contact their Matron/Manager who can attend the ward/department or will make contact with the complainant to resolve the issue.
10.3.5 Where concerns remain, patients must be made aware that they can contact the PALS & Complaints Department and relevant contact details provided.
PALS- Enquiries & Concerns

PALS aims to provide signposting to appropriate services, advice where possible/appropriate and support to patients, service users, carers and relatives. PALS aims to ensure speedy resolution for those patients, service users, carers and relatives who seek an explanation regarding an enquiry or concern.

Each hospital site has a dedicated PALS Team who are accessible via a dedicated telephone service and site PALS email account. These are accessible to service users via the Trust website. There is also the facility to book a virtual PALS appointment via the PALS Team (on the “attend anywhere” platform) enabling patients, carers, relatives etc to meet face to face with PALS staff and/or other appropriate Trust staff to discuss concerns.
Enquiries and PALS concerns cover a large number of issues and should be resolved within 5 working days of receipt. These are often communicated verbally, or in writing (email/letter).
The PALS Officers log all Enquiries and PALS concerns onto the Datix DCIQ database recording the main details.

The enquiry or PALS concern is sent by the PALS Team to the relevant staff within the appropriate division(s) for resolution, where a swift investigation is undertaken by the appropriate staff to establish the facts to enable a response.

The appropriate staff within the division are responsible for ensuring that the patient/complainant is contacted directly, within the required timeframe, to provide an explanation and a response to the points they have raised through the PALS service. Responses are generally verbal but can also be in writing. If a written response is required, this should be sent from an appropriate member of staff from the division.

Restricted access to the Datix DCIQ database is granted to identified relevant divisional staff to enable them to update the PALS or enquiry records on Datix DCIQ. All updates should be entered onto the case, including learning/recommendations and investigation details. Relevant staff within the division are responsible for closing the PALS concern/enquiry on the Datix DCIQ database.
Formal Complaints

A formal complaint is often (but not always) raised after the event and requires a full investigation to take place. Formal complaints may be received by telephone, email or letter. Formal complaints require a written response and/or meeting with staff (with a follow up summary letter) to fully address the concerns raised.

If the concerns are raised verbally, a written record of the concerns should be taken by the member of staff, in the words of the complainant. This should be typed up and sent to the complainant to request confirmation that it is a true record of their
concerns. Once confirmation has been received from the complainant, the complaint can be investigated.

The complaint will be allocated to the relevant division who will appoint an investigating officer who will take a closer look into the issues raised. This will always involve taking a detailed and fair review of these issues to determine what happened.

Where possible, complaints will be looked at by someone not involved in the events complained about. If this is not possible, we will explain to the person making the complaint the reasons why it was assigned to that person. This should address any perceived conflict of interest.
Clarifying the complaint and explaining the process

12.5.1 When a formal complaint is received the Complaints Team will ensure the case is logged onto the Datix DCIQ Database, triaged (see point below) and an acknowledgement letter sent to the complainant within 3 working days of receipt. The acknowledgment letter will set out the timescale of the investigation and response.

12.5.2 Complaints are triaged/rated by the PALS & Complaints Team for internal purposes to help identify potential or actual serious cases, and to assist with identifying cases where concerns are raised that directly impact patient care.
12.5.3 The RAG Rating Triage is as follows:

table_items.text: The complaint is about an unexpected death, potential/actual SI, possible claim for clinical negligence, adverse publicity or financial implications for the Trust.
Concerns directly affect patient care and treatment (e.g. nursing or doctor care, delays in treatment, poor communication etc)
Concerns do not directly affect the patient care and treatment (e.g. environmental issues, staff attitude, estates issues etc)

data.text: 12.5.4 When the formal complaint is sent by the Complaints Team to the division for investigation, in most cases the division will be expected to make a courtesy call to the complainant to discuss the complaint. This will usually be the Investigating Officer and they will:
Engage with the person raising the complaint to make sure they fully understand and agree:
Explain how they will carry out the investigation into the complaint including:
Carrying out the investigation

12.6.1 Staff who carry out investigations will give a clear, balanced explanation of what happened and what should have happened. They will reference relevant standards, policies and guidance to clearly identify if something has gone wrong.

12.6.2 The investigating officer will make sure the investigation clearly addresses all the issues raised. This includes obtaining evidence from any staff involved in the investigation, and could also include speaking with the person raising the complaint (this could be as part of the courtesy call at the beginning of the investigation). If the complaint raised clinical issues the investigating officer will ensure the patient's medical records are reviewed and will obtain a clinical view from someone suitably qualified. Ideally they should not have been directly involved in providing the care or service that has been complained about.

12.6.3 Where more than one division is involved in the investigation, the lead division will be responsible for liaising with the other divisions to ensure a cohesive investigation nans response. The divisions are expected to liaise and work together to complete the final response letter.
12.6.4 We will complete our investigation within the timescale set out at the start of the investigation. Should circumstances change the relevant division will:
Notify the person raising the complaint immediately
Explain the reasons for the delay
Provide a new target timescale for completion
Providing a remedy

12.7.1 If, following the investigation the investigating officer identifies that something has gone wrong they will seek to establish what impact the failing has had on the individual concerned. Where possible they will put that right. If it is not possible to put the matter right they will decide in discussion with the individual concerned and relevant staff, what action can be taken to remedy the impact.
12.7.2 In order to put things right, the following remedies may be appropriate
An acknowledgement and a meaningful apology for the error
Reconsideration of a previous decision
Expediting an action
Waiving a fee or penalty
Changing policies and procedures to prevent the same mistake(s) happening again and to improve our service for others
The final written response

12.8.1 After the investigation is finished, the Investigating Officer will compile a written response (to be sent from the relevant Managing Director or their representative), as well as identify any learning and recommendations.

12.8.2 Once the letter is written, the Divisional Leadership Team will ensure approval of all information including the clinical information, within the letter. The letter will be expected to address all points raised in the original complaint letter, as well as the points discussed during the courtesy call, and will be written in plain terms, providing explanations and apologies where necessary.

12.8.3 The Divisional Leadership Team will approve learning and recommendations identified during the investigation, which will be confirmed within the response letter. These recommendations and lessons learned will be recording as “actions” onto the Datix DCIQ database by the divisions.

12.8.4 Where more than one division is involved in the investigation, the lead division will be responsible for collating the responses from the other division(s) into one letter. The divisions are expected to liaise and work together to complete the final response letter.

12.8.5 The letter will be sent to the Complaints Team once approved within the division. The Complaints Team will sense check and ensure the letter is clearly written, is appropriate in relation to tone, empathy, language etc. The letter will then be sent to the site based Managing Director for signing.
12.8.6 Once the letter has been signed, the complaints team will send this to the person raising the complaint and any other interested parties. The response will include:
a reminder of the issues investigated and the outcome sought
an explanation of how we investigated the complaint
the relevant evidence we considered
what the outcome is
an explanation of whether or not something went wrong that sets out what happened compared to what should have happened, with reference to relevant standards, policies and guidance
if something did go wrong, an explanation of the impact it had
an explanation of how that impact will be remedied for the individual
a meaningful apology for any failings
an explanation of any wider learning we have acted on/will act on to improve our service for other users
an explanation of how we will keep the person raising the complaint involved until all action has been carried out
confirmation that we have reached the end of our complaint procedure
details of how to contact the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman if the individual is not satisfied with our final response
Meetings

12.9.1 It is recognised that offering a complainant the opportunity to fully discuss their complaint at a meeting is often a successful way of resolving cases more effectively, in particular more difficult and complex cases.

12.9.2 It is the responsibility of the division(s) involved to make the necessary arrangements with the complainant and keep the Complaints Team updated. When arranging a meeting every effort should be made to make the complainant comfortable, paying attention to the number of attendees and where the meeting is held etc.
12.9.3 Prior to the meeting it is advisable for staff involved to have a pre-meeting to ensure they can provide any facts and support during the meeting.

12.9.4 Complaints meetings can be recorded by the divisions with the consent of all parties present, with a copy of the recording being provided to the Complainant following the meeting, and a further copy being held within the PALS & Complaints Team. The division must also compile a letter following the meeting, which summarises the discussions and any action points agreed before the complaint can be closed.
12.9.5 Following the meeting, staff attending should debrief and where necessary emotional support should be offered to staff affected by the complaint e.g Occupational Health
Reopened Complaints
12.10.1 When the final response letter is sent, complainants are advised to contact the PALS

& Complaints Team if they do not consider the information provided in the final response has satisfactorily resolved their concerns. If this is the case, they will be invited to further outline/discuss their concerns with the Complaints Team.
12.10.2 If a further response is required, the Trust will investigate and respond to the reopened complaint within the usual set timeframe, following the same complaints process.

12.10.3 If a complainant contacts the department after a significant delay, the PALS & Complaints Manager will review the complaint and the reason for the delayed contact from the complainant, and make a decision as to whether the case can be further investigated, taking into account the time that has passed, and whether it would be possible to carry out a further investigation effectively or fairly.
Referral to the Ombudsman

12.11.1 In our response on every complaint we will clearly inform the person raising the complaint that if they are not happy with the outcome of our investigation, they can take their complaint to the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman (PHSO).

12.11.2 If the complainant remains dissatisfied when local resolution has been deemed as completed they have the option to ask the PHSO to undertake an independent review of their case. The Trust will cooperate fully with any investigation of its complaints handling by the PHSO.

12.11.3 The PALS & Complaints Teams will liaise with the relevant division(s) regarding any investigations or recommendations received from the PHSO and ensure appropriate responses and action is taken.
Complaints involving multiple organisations

On receipt of a complaint the PALS & Complaints Team will decide whether external agencies such as the social services, other healthcare providers, police, coroner etc should be involved in the investigation.

Where services are provided jointly by Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and another provider, or a complaint involves another provider of NHS treatment, the organisation receiving the complaint must contact the complainant seeking their consent to work jointly with the other organisations to resolve the complaint. Agreement must then be reached between the organisations on which provider will lead on the complaint and provide a joint response to the complainant. The complainant should be informed of this arrangement.

Should the complainant wish to receive separate responses from each organisation then (following receipt of the appropriate consent to do so) the complaint will be passed to the other organisations for direct response to the complainant and the Trust will investigate and respond to only the issues that pertain to care and treatment provided by Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

Should the complainant not wish for the involvement of other organisations then the Trust will investigate and respond to only the issues that pertain to care and treatment provided by Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

The complaints procedure does not cover complaints about private medical treatment provided in an NHS setting. However, it does cover any complaint made relating to NHS staff or facilities relative to care in a private payment bed. These cases should be documented on the Datix DCIQ database for reference. Where no concerns are raised about NHS services provided by Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust in relation to Private Care received, then these cases should not be recorded on the Trust's Datix DCIQ database.
Managing habitual/prolific/vexatious Complainants

A complainant may become habitual or vexatious at any stage during a complaint, however, more often this occurs after the final complaint response is sent or after a final meeting has been held. If staff are concerned that a complainant may be classified as habitual or vexatious, they should contact the PALS & Complaints Team without delay where support will be provided. Full guidance on how to manage habitual or vexatious complainants is contained within the Appendix 2 of this policy.
Support for staff

It is essential that the complaint outcome should achieve a mutually acceptable resolution for the complainant, whilst being conscientiously fair to staff. The purpose of the complaints procedure is not to apportion blame amongst staff but to ensure that any lessons learned for improvement in service delivery are shared and
implemented throughout the organisation, and with the complainant. The complaints procedure is not the appropriate or correct route for staff grievances.

It is essential that all investigations be conducted in a manner that is supportive to those involved. The process is best described as listening, learning and improving. Any member of staff cited in a complaint must be informed of the details of the complaint. It is the responsibility of the Investigating Officer to ensure this happens. A copy of the final response letter to the complaint should be shared with the staff member(s) before it is sent to the complainant. The staff member(s) cannot investigate or respond to the complaint directly and they cannot veto the content or style of the final reply.

In situations where staff have been exposed to traumatic experiences either as a consequence of the cause of a complaint, the investigation, or the actions of the complainant or representatives, the opportunity of support from the Occupational Health Service or their line manager should be explored by the relevant divisional Senior Leadership Team. A debrief meeting should be considered and held if appropriate.

The Complaints Teams are available to advise staff who are leading the investigation and provide support to staff that are involved in complaints investigations. In addition to the practical support offered to staff outlined in the above procedures, staff have access to existing support services such as:
Trust in house counselling service for face to face support
Independent 24/7 telephone helpline CiC 0800 085 1376

Staff that have professional concerns about services/care being provided should refer to the Trust's Raising Concerns (Whistleblowing) policy (MSEPO-21154). The policy sets out how to raise concerns about potential risks, malpractices or wrongdoing, breaches of law, regulations or similar concerns.

The complaints investigation process must be kept separate from any disciplinary procedures and, if any action involving members of staff is taken as a consequence of a complaint investigation, then the detail of this must not be shared with the complainant in accordance with current employment legislation.

When involved in challenging situations staff, patients, carers and visitors should treat each other with respect at all times. Violence, racial, sexual or verbal harassment will not be tolerated under any circumstances. Neither will language that is of a personal, abusive or threatening nature.
Monitoring, demonstrating learning and data recording

We expect all staff to identify what learning can be taken from complaints, regardless of whether mistakes are found or not. Our Senior Managers take an active interest and involvement in all sources of feedback and complaints, identifying what insight and learning will help improve our services for other users.

It is imperative that lessons are learnt from complaints and that we use all feedback to drive service improvements. To give credibility to our complaints process, we must be able to assure complainants that action will be taken to improve the patient experience in future and be sure that we can monitor this.

The Investigating Officer will identify lessons learnt and recommendations as part of their investigation. These will be explained within the final response letter and sent to the Division Senior Leadership Team for approval.

Learning and recommendations identified will be entered by the divisions onto the Datix DCIQ database as an action. The action should give a brief summary of the issue and the learning or action to be taken (e.g. new policy to be written and implemented/staff training etc). Generally a timeframe of 6 weeks should be given for recommendations to be implemented, although in some cases a longer time period may be required to fully implement a change.

A lead for the action is identified (e.g. Senior Ward Sister, department lead, Matron etc) and this is the person responsible and accountable for ensuring that the recommendation is implemented and completed.

16.6 The action will remain active on the Datix DCIQ Database until the lead completes and provides evidence that the action has been implemented. Once this has been done detail of the evidence should be entered onto the Datix DCIQ Database for proof of implementation and the action can then be closed.

A weekly report is produced for each site Director of Nursing detailing all active and breached cases for each site. This is disseminated to the divisions with the Care Groups to ensure that divisions are actively addressing and monitoring cases. Divisions also have access to Dashboards on the Datix DCIQ Database detailing real-time data in relation to PALS concerns and Complaints for their areas.

A monthly report is provided to the Quality Governance Group (QGG) with exception reporting, detailing numbers received, themes and trends, performance and any other key issues relating to complaints handling.

A quarterly report on complaints is sent to the QGG and the Quality Governance Committee (QGC) detailing numbers received, themes and trends, performance and any other key issues relating to complaints handling.
The Trust publishes an annual report on complaints handling, copies of which will be available on the Trust's website. This information is also included in the Trusts annual reports.

The quarterly KO41(a) report is submitted to NHS Digital. The information obtained in the KO41(a) collection monitors written hospital and community health service complaints (by service area and type) received.
Training requirements
Outline training requirements or if not appropriate state:
15.1.1 The PALS & Complaints Team can provide bespoke training sessions to divisions if requested.
15.1.2 All new staff receive Patient Experience (including PALS & Complaints) awareness training on Trust induction.

15.1.3 A PALS & Complaints handling toolkit is available to support staff with their responsibilities and the PALS & Complaints process. This is available via the Trust's learning platform and upon request from the PALS & Complaints Teams.
Monitoring and Audit

The PALS & Complaints Manager and the Head of PALS & Complaints will ensure that any changes or updates to the national regulations or the PHSO NHS Complaints Standards will be acted upon and the policy updated.
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Response performance and breached complaints (cases not responded to within the initial agreed timeframe)
Reported by exception to MSE Quality Governance Group
Review of triaging of contacts logged onto DCIQ database

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Head of PALS & Complaints and the Associate Director of Patient Experience, with the authority to approve local PALS & Complaints guidance. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform relevant staff groups of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 3)
References
The Local Authority Social Services and National Health Service Complaints (England) Regulations 2009
Parliamentary & Health Service Ombudsman: NHS Complaints Standards
Appendix 1: Roles and Responsibilities Appendix
Certain Members of the Trust have specific duties when dealing with PALS and Complaints, as set out in the following table:

table_items.text: Must be informed of the organisations effective management and reporting of all complaints. Ensuring that the Trust has an effective system in place for the management, response and learning from the complaints process.

To report on monthly, quarterly and annual numbers, themes and issues arising from PALS & Complaints. To ensure that there is learning and improvement as a result of effective complaints management and that key themes are investigated through triangulation of data from all Patient Experience feedback.

Analysis of key themes and issues arising in complaints within the divisions by analysis of the quarterly report. Ensure there is shared learning and improvement as a result of effective complaints management within the divisions.
Ultimate executive accountability for the quality of services and is the Trust “responsible person” under the Complaints Regulations.

Will ensure all medical staff comply with the Trust Complaints Policy and through the process of validation will ensure all medical staff learn from the outcome of complaints and remedial action when necessary to improve future experiences.

Accountable Executive for Patient Experience and PALS & Complaints for the Trust, ensuring that the Trust has a robust policy for the handling of PALS & Complaints, and that all staff comply to this. Ensures the provision of strong professional leadership to all staff to ensure a culture of care and compassion is embedded throughout the teams in handling complaints.

Will sign final written responses to formal complaints and meet with complainants where necessary. At times of annual leave or absence for other reasons, the Managing Director will nominate an Executive Director to sign written responses on their behalf (usually the Director of Nursing).
Is accountable to the site Managing Director and the Chief Nurse for ensuring that the divisions within the Care Groups provide complaint responses that are accurate, compassionate and fair.
Site based provision of strong professional leadership to site based staff to ensure a culture of care and compassion is embedded throughout the teams in handling complaints.
To deputise for the site Director of Nursing on the management of complaints as appropriate.
Divisional Directors / Clinical Directors / Associate Directors of Nursing / Matrons / Heads of Departments

Are responsible for ensuring robust systems are in place within their areas of responsibility to facilitate full and appropriate investigations and responses to complaints. Identifying, monitoring and implementing service improvements in relation to patient safety and patient experience issues identified as a consequence of complaints.

Overall responsibility for the PALS & Complaints Teams and overall compliance of the Trust's complaints process in line with the National Regulations. Ensuring that complaints are dealt with appropriately and overseeing that the complaints process is fulfilled. The provision of complaint and learning reports as required by internal and external organisations. They will act as the primary liaison for the Trust with the Parliamentary & Health Service Ombudsman (PHSO). They have overall responsibility for the management of complaints and will provide guidance, support and advice to both the PALS & Complaints staff and the divisional staff in the resolution of concerns and complaints.

Responsible for the day to day management of the PALS & Complaints teams; supporting teams with all new concerns and complaints and the management of complex cases. Providing advice and guidance to divisions on the effecting handling and resolution of concerns and complaints. Responsible for the overall compliance of the Trust's complaints process in line with National Complaints Regulations. Act as main lead on PHSO cases, providing leadership and guidance to divisional and complaints staff on these cases. Meeting with divisional leads to manage and advise on open and breached cases.

Day to day line management of the PALS & Complaints teams. Ensuring appropriate triage and management of new concerns and complaints, providing appropriate support to the divisions for the handling of all concerns and complaints, including cases with the PHSO, complex cases and cases received via MPs.

Responsible for the logging and monitoring of complaints, liaising with staff, external stakeholders and complainants. The Complaints Officers are responsible for directing the investigation process and ensuring that complaints are dealt with in line with the process and within appropriate timescales.

Responsible for the logging and monitoring of enquiries and concerns. Provide signposting to appropriate services, advice and support to service users to ensure speedy resolution to enquiries raised by patients, service users, carers and relatives.

Each Directorate has the responsibility, via designated governance leads, to ensure the completion of timely, accurate and high quality information in response to any request by the complaints teams, verbal or in writing in the resolution of a concern or complaint.

data.text: Appendix 2: Guidance on Vexatious Complainants

Complainants (and/or anyone acting on their behalf) may be deemed to be habitual or vexatious complainants where previous or current contact with them shows that they meet one or more of the following criteria:
Insist in pursuing a complaint where the NHS complaints procedure has been fully and properly implemented and exhausted

Change the substance of a complaint or continually raise new issues or seek to prolong contact by continually raising further concerns of questions upon receipt of a response or whilst the complaint is being addressed. Due care must be taken not to disregard any new issues that have been raised which are significantly different from the original complaint and these may need to be addressed as part of the on- going complaint or as a separate complaint.

Are unwilling to accept documented evidence of treatment given as being factual (for example drug records, clinician records or nursing records) or deny receipt of an adequate response in spite of correspondence specifically answering their questions or do not accept that facts can sometimes be difficult to verify when a long period of time has elapsed.

Do not clearly identify the precise issues that they wish to be investigated, despite reasonable efforts of Trust Staff to help them specify their concerns, and/or where the concerns identified are not with the remit of the Trust.

In the course of addressing a logged complaint, have had an excessive number of contacts with the Trust, placing unreasonable demands on staff. A contact may be in person, by telephone or email. Reasonable discretion must be applied when determining the precise number of excessive contacts applicable under this section using judgment on an individual case by case basis.

If behaviour is unreasonable/harassing/bullying/abusive or aggressive. Staff must recognise that complainants may sometimes act out of character at times of stress, anxiety or distress and should make reasonable allowances for this. They should however ensure that they do document all incidents or harassment on the Incident Module of the Datix DCIQ database.
Are known to have recorded face to face meetings or telephone conversations without the prior knowledge and/or consent from the other parties involved.

Focus on a matter that is out of proportion to its significance and continuing to focus on this point. It is recognised that determining what is justified can be subjective and careful judgment must be used in applying this criterion.

Display unreasonable demands and fail to accept that these may be unreasonable for example; insisting on responses to complaints or PALS concerns being provided more urgently than is reasonable and recognised normal practice.
Where it would appear that a complainant is prolific or vexatious in accordance with the above criteria a member of the PALS & Complaints Team will escalate to the PALS & Complaints Manager

The PALS & Complaints Manager will then review if the criteria has been met. If the criteria have been met the case will be presented to the Head of PALS & Complaints and the Associate Director for Patient Experience and the appropriate divisional lead. They will then determine what action to take.
The Associate Director for Patient Experience, Head of PALS & Complaints and appropriate divisional lead will inform the PALS & Complaints Manager accordingly of their decision.
The PALS & Complaints Manager will then implement such action and will notify complainants in writing of the reasons why they have been classified as prolific or vexatious.

Once it has been established that the complainant meets any of the criteria above, it may be appropriate to inform them in writing that they may be classified as habitual or vexatious complainants moving forward. They will then need to receive a copy of this procedure and be advised to take into account this procedure in any further dealings with the Trust.

Each of these options must be considered on an individual case by case basis to ensure that the approach being applied is appropriate, reasonable and proportionate. The Associate Director for Patient Experience and appropriate divisional leads may decide to deal with complaints in one or more of the following ways:

Try to resolve matters by drawing up a signed “agreement” with the complainant (if appropriate, involving all parties involved) which sets out a code of conduct/process for the parties involved to follow if the Trust will continue to process complaint. If these terms were contravened at any point then consideration would be given to implement other options listed below.

Decline contact with the complainant either in person, by telephone, email or letter, or any combination of these, provided that one form of contact is maintained or alternatively to restrict contact liaison through a third party, such as an advocate or person acting on the complainants behalf. If staff are to withdraw from a telephone conversation with such a complainant it may be useful for them to have a written script to follow on these occasions.

Notify the complainant in writing that the Managing Director has fully responded to the points that they have raised and has tried to resolve the complaint but that there is nothing more to add and that continuing contact on the matter is not possible. Complainant should also be notified that the correspondence is at an end and that further letters received by the Trust will be acknowledged but not answered.

Inform complainant that in extreme circumstances that in extreme circumstances the Trust reserves the right to pass unreasonable or vexatious complaints to the Trust Security and Legal Team. Temporarily suspend all contact with the complainant or investigation of a complaint whilst seeking legal advice or relevant guidance on the matter.

Once complainants have been determined as prolific or vexatious, there must also be a process for withdrawing that status. This will be necessary for example if a complainant subsequently demonstrates a more reasonable approach or if they submit a further complaint for which the normal complaints procedure would appear appropriate.

Staff should previously have used their discretion in recommending habitual or vexatious status at the outset and so discretion should similarly be used in recommending that the status be withdrawn when deemed appropriate.

The ultimate decision to withdraw the status rests with the Associate Director for Patient Experience and the appropriate divisional lead. Subject to such approval, normal contact with the complainant will be resumed.
